        "I'm trying to copy a file called '?checkpoint' from the salt master to  a minion. My SLS file looks like this:

```
/etc/marathon/conf/?checkpoint:
  file.managed:
    - source: salt://hw/config/?checkpoint
    - makedirs: True
```

When running the state I get a

```
----------
          ID: /etc/marathon/conf/?checkpoint
    Function: file.managed
      Result: False
     Comment: Source file salt://hw/config/?checkpoint not found
     Started: 10:27:53.648561
    Duration: 54.034 ms
     Changes:
----------
```

(the file does exist of course)

I've tried all kinds of escaping like

```
    - source: salt://hw/config/\?checkpoint
    - source: "salt://hw/config/?checkpoint"
    - source: 'salt://hw/config/?checkpoint'
```

But none seems to work. What's the correct way to reference this file in my SLS?

{ "id": 49516688, "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/18308", "body": "Sometimes I'll get **Error: There was a profile error: Failed to authenticate against remote windows host** errors:\n\n
\n    root@ip-172-31-42-67:/srv/salt# salt-cloud -p win2008-splunk-indexer cchung-win-idx                                                                                                                          \n    [INFO    ] salt-cloud starting\n    [INFO    ] Creating Cloud VM cchung-win-idx in us-east-1\n    [INFO    ] Attempting to look up root device name for image id ami-3e168356 on VM cchung-win-idx\n    [INFO    ] Found root device name: /dev/sda1\n    [INFO    ] Created node cchung-win-idx\n    [INFO    ] Salt node data. Private_ip: 172.31.45.15\n    [INFO    ] Running command under pid 14257: 'winexe -U Administrator%pass //172.31.45.15 \"hostname\"'\n    Error: There was a profile error: Failed to authenticate against remote windows host\n
\n\nIt's raised by **wait_for_instance** (https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/2014.7/salt/cloud/clouds/ec2.py#L1789), and because there is no retry mechanism in **validate_windows_cred** (https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/2014.7/salt/utils/cloud.py#L689).\n\nso there will be couple seconds (longer for the smaller machine) that the windows machine is ready, but the windows service isnt ready for accepting connections yet (1 & 0 are return codes from winexe command.):\n\n
\n    ERROR: Failed to open connection - NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_REFUSED\n    1\n    ERROR: Failed to open connection - NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_REFUSED\n    1\n    ERROR: Failed to open connection - NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_REFUSED\n    1\n    ERROR: Failed to open connection - NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_RESET\n    1\n    WIN-97SVH1E1AAJ\n    0\n    WIN-97SVH1E1AAJ\n    0\n
\n\nThis causes the **validate_windows_cred** to return false, then the exception is raised. \nSimply add the retry to **validate_windows_cred** will resolve this issue:\n\n
\ndef validate_windows_cred(host, username='Administrator', password=None, retries=10):\n    '''    Check if the windows credentials are valid    '''\n    for i in xrange(retries):\n        retcode = win_cmd('winexe -U {0}%{1} //{2} \"hostname\"'.format(\n            username, password, host\n        ))\n        if retcode == 0: break\n        time.sleep(1)\n    return retcode == 0\n
\n\noutputs (note there are two lines of winexe commands):\n
\n    root@ip-172-31-42-67:/srv/salt# salt-cloud -p win2008-splunk-indexer cchung-win-idx                                                                                              \n    [INFO    ] salt-cloud starting[INFO    ] Creating Cloud VM cchung-win-idx in us-east-1\n    [INFO    ] Attempting to look up root device name for image id ami-3e168356 on VM cchung-win-idx\n    [INFO    ] Found root device name: /dev/sda1\n    [INFO    ] Created node cchung-win-idx\n    [INFO    ] Salt node data. Private_ip: 172.31.32.233\n    [INFO    ] Running command under pid 21253: 'winexe -U Administrator%pass //172.31.32.233 \"hostname\"'\n    [INFO    ] Running command under pid 21446: 'winexe -U Administrator%pass //172.31.32.233 \"hostname\"'\n    WIN-97SVH1E1AAJ\n
\n\n\nCan someone help us to resolve this? It happens sometimes, but it causes our provisioning process unstable. I'll love to do a pull request if everyone is busy, thanks!\n", "user": { "id": 5371682, "url": "https://api.github.com/users/billcchung", "type": "User", "login": "billcchung", "node_id": { "body": [ "Sometimes I'll get **Error: There was a profile error: Failed to authenticate against remote windows host** errors: 
    root@ip-172-31-42-67:/srv/salt# salt-cloud -p win2008-splunk-indexer cchung-win-idx                                                                                                                          
    [INFO    ] salt-cloud starting
    [INFO    ] Creating Cloud VM cchung-win-idx in us-east-1
    [INFO    ] Attempting to look up root device name for image id ami-3e168356 on VM cchung-win-idx
    [INFO    ] Found root device name: /dev/sda1
    [INFO    ] Created node cchung-win-idx
    [INFO    ] Salt node data. Private_ip: 172.31.45.15
    [INFO    ] Running command under pid 14257: 'winexe -U Administrator%pass //172.31.45.15 "hostname"'
    Error: There was a profile error: Failed to authenticate against remote windows host
It's raised by **wait_for_instance** (https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/2014.7/salt/cloud/clouds/ec2.py#L1789), and because there is no retry mechanism in **validate_windows_cred** (https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/2014.7/salt/utils/cloud.py#L689). so there will be couple seconds (longer for the smaller machine) that the windows machine is ready, but the windows service isnt ready for accepting connections yet (1 & 0 are return codes from winexe command.): 
    ERROR: Failed to open connection - NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_REFUSED
    1
    ERROR: Failed to open connection - NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_REFUSED
    1
    ERROR: Failed to open connection - NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_REFUSED
    1
    ERROR: Failed to open connection - NT_STATUS_CONNECTION_RESET
    1
    WIN-97SVH1E1AAJ
    0
    WIN-97SVH1E1AAJ
    0
This causes the **validate_windows_cred** to return false, then the exception is raised. Simply add the retry to **validate_windows_cred** will resolve this issue: 

def validate_windows_cred(host, username='Administrator', password=None, retries=10):
    '''    Check if the windows credentials are valid    '''
    for i in xrange(retries):
        retcode = win_cmd('winexe -U {0}%{1} //{2} "hostname"'.format(
            username, password, host
        ))
        if retcode == 0: break
        time.sleep(1)
    return retcode == 0
outputs (note there are two lines of winexe commands): 
    root@ip-172-31-42-67:/srv/salt# salt-cloud -p win2008-splunk-indexer cchung-win-idx                                                                                              
    [INFO    ] salt-cloud starting[INFO    ] Creating Cloud VM cchung-win-idx in us-east-1
    [INFO    ] Attempting to look up root device name for image id ami-3e168356 on VM cchung-win-idx
    [INFO    ] Found root device name: /dev/sda1
    [INFO    ] Created node cchung-win-idx
    [INFO    ] Salt node data. Private_ip: 172.31.32.233
    [INFO    ] Running command under pid 21253: 'winexe -U Administrator%pass //172.31.32.233 "hostname"'
    [INFO    ] Running command under pid 21446: 'winexe -U Administrator%pass //172.31.32.233 "hostname"'
    WIN-97SVH1E1AAJ
Can someone help us to resolve this? It happens sometimes, but it causes our provisioning process unstable. I'll love to do a pull request if everyone is busy, thanks! {
    "id": 76109479,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/23687",
    "body": "Newer versions of the docker client (1.6.0+) support a `security_opt` keyword to control privileges provided to a container (see [client.py:start()](https://github.com/docker/docker-py/blob/master/docker/client.py)). This particular option is very important for debian/ubuntu users due to [docker issue 7276 with apparmor](https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/7276) that will overrun the system logs with a huge amount of warnings.\n\nCurrently, there is no way to use the docker.\\* salt states and set this option. The only work around, so far as I'm aware, is to manually build out a docker start command.\n\n----- UPDATE -----\n\nDue to our environment, I ended up having to create a monkey patch to add in this behavior. For anybody else in desperate need of a temporary solution, feel free to use [our monkey patch](https://github.com/xetus-oss/salt-docker-monkeypatched-module/tree/master)\n",

    "body": "**Description**
When a playbook or ansible.call run is issued and fails, Saltstack doesn't report a failure.

**Setup**
I don't have a great example... I'm testing with Ansible's GCE modules/cloud modules for orchestration purposes...

_Salt state example_
```
{% set name = 'test-instance %}
{% set domain = 'example.lcl' %}
{% set service_account_file = '/path/to/serviceaccount/keyfile.json' %}
{% set project = 'my-gce-project %}
{% set zone = 'us-west1-a' %}
{% set machine_type = 'n1-standard-1' %}
{% set image = 'projects/suse-byos-cloud/global/images/sles-15-sp1-byos-v20200610' %}
{%
    set network_interfaces = [
                               { 'network': { 'selfLink': "projects/my-gce-project/global/networks/default" },
                                 'subnetwork': { 'selfLink': "projects/my-gce-project/regions/us-west1/subnetworks/default" } },
                             ]
%}

{% set ansible_kwargs = {'extra_vars':
                            { 'name': name,
                              'domain': domain,
                              'service_account_file': service_account_file,
                              'project': project,
                              'zone': zone,
                              'machine_type': machine_type,
                              'image': image,
                              'network_interfaces': network_interfaces

                            }
       }
%}

orch_instance_gcp_deployed:
    module.run:
        - name: ansible.playbooks
        - playbook: /srv/salt/orch/instance/gcp/playbooks/playbook-deployed.yml
        - check: False
        - extra_vars: {{ ansible_kwargs['extra_vars'] | tojson }}
```
_ansible playbook example:_
```
- name: Create GCP Instance
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: no

  tasks:
  - name: Create a GCP Instance
    gcp_compute_instance:
        name: "{{ name }}"
        hostname: "{{ name }}.{{ domain }}"
        machine_type: "{{ machine_type }}"
        disks:
            - auto_delete: True
              boot: yes
              initialize_params:
                  source_image: "{{ image }}"
                  disk_size_gb: 40
        network_interfaces: "{{ network_interfaces }}"
        zone: "{{ zone }}"
        project: "{{ project }}"
        auth_kind: serviceaccount
        service_account_file: "{{ service_account_file }}"
        state: present
```
**Steps to Reproduce the behavior**
If the above state is run twice, it will produce an error (since the instance already exists). Salt will mark it as successful with changes. 

If you choose to use the above example, you'll need to create a gcp service account in a gcp project and acquire a service account key. https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/creating-managing-service-account-keys
**Expected behavior**
Salt should report it as failed.

{%
    set network_interfaces = [
                               { 'network': { 'selfLink': "projects/my-gce-project/global/networks/default" },
                                 'subnetwork': { 'selfLink': "projects/my-gce-project/regions/us-west1/subnetworks/default" } },
                             ]
%}

{% set ansible_kwargs = {'extra_vars':
                            { 'name': name,
                              'domain': domain,
                              'service_account_file': service_account_file,
                              'project': project,
                              'zone': zone,
                              'machine_type': machine_type,
                              'image': image,
                              'network_interfaces': network_interfaces

                            }
       }
%}

orch_instance_gcp_deployed:
    module.run:
        - name: ansible.playbooks
        - playbook: /srv/salt/orch/instance/gcp/playbooks/playbook-deployed.yml
        - check: False
        - extra_vars: {{ ansible_kwargs['extra_vars'] | tojson }}
```
_ansible playbook example:_
```
- name: Create GCP Instance
  hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: no

  tasks:
  - name: Create a GCP Instance
    gcp_compute_instance:
        name: "{{ name }}"
        hostname: "{{ name }}.{{ domain }}"
        machine_type: "{{ machine_type }}"
        disks:
            - auto_delete: True
              boot: yes
              initialize_params:
                  source_image: "{{ image }}"
                  disk_size_gb: 40
        network_interfaces: "{{ network_interfaces }}"
        zone: "{{ zone }}"
        project: "{{ project }}"
        auth_kind: serviceaccount
        service_account_file: "{{ service_account_file }}"
        state: present
```
**Steps to Reproduce the behavior**
If the above state is run twice, it will produce an error (since the instance already exists). Salt will mark it as successful with changes. 

If you choose to use the above example, you'll need to create a gcp service account in a gcp project and acquire a service account key. https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/creating-managing-service-account-keys
**Expected behavior**
Salt should report it as failed.

    "id": 767052931,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/38484",
    "body": "- [x] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

~~- [ ] I have confirmed this bug exists on the latest version of pandas.~~ (Not applicable)

~~- [ ] (optional) I have confirmed this bug exists on the master branch of pandas.~~ (Not applicable)

---

**Note**: Please read [this guide](https://matthewrocklin.com/blog/work/2018/02/28/minimal-bug-reports) detailing how to provide the necessary information for us to reproduce your bug.

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example

```python
import pyarrow.parquet as pq

pq.read_table(None)
```

#### Problem description

The above snippet will produce a Segmentation Fault, which is highly undesirable. The reason I discovered this, was I had a function that was supposed to return a filepath, but on my first iteration I forgot to return. Thus, when I ran my module with `pq.read_table(generate_fp())`, it produced a Segmentation Fault.

#### Expected Output

Ideally this will raise an `ValueError`, indicating to the user that `None` is an invalid source/filepath.

{
    "body": [
        "- [x] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

~~- [ ] I have confirmed this bug exists on the latest version of pandas.~~ (Not applicable)

~~- [ ] (optional) I have confirmed this bug exists on the master branch of pandas.~~ (Not applicable)

---

**Note**: Please read [this guide](https://matthewrocklin.com/blog/work/2018/02/28/minimal-bug-reports) detailing how to provide the necessary information for us to reproduce your bug.

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example

```python
import pyarrow.parquet as pq

pq.read_table(None)
```

#### Problem description

The above snippet will produce a Segmentation Fault, which is highly undesirable. The reason I discovered this, was I had a function that was supposed to return a filepath, but on my first iteration I forgot to return. Thus, when I ran my module with `pq.read_table(generate_fp())`, it produced a Segmentation Fault.

#### Expected Output

Ideally this will raise an `ValueError`, indicating to the user that `None` is an invalid source/filepath.

{
    "id": 460594998,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/13834",
    "body": "When the first argument to `np.testing.assert_array_less` is a scalar, the mismatch percentage reported is 100% * <number of mismatched items>, which can be arbitrarily large.\r\n\r\nThe error seems to be in `numpy.testing._private.utils.assert_array_compare` on [this line](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/a1cd310ea6192945b7f4e452ad5794b291da77a5/numpy/testing/_private/utils.py#L807):\r\n\r\n```python\r\nmismatch = 100. * (reduced.size - reduced.sum(dtype=intp)) / ox.size\r\n```\r\n\r\nMaybe that line could be:\r\n\r\n```python\r\nmismatch = 100. * (reduced.size - reduced.sum(dtype=intp)) / max(ox.size, oy.size)\r\n```\r\n\r\nI would be happy to implement such a small fix and write a test for it if someone is able to review it.\r\n\r\n### Reproducing code example:\r\n\r\n<!-- A short code example that reproduces the problem/missing feature. It should be\r\nself-contained, i.e., possible to run as-is via 'python myproblem.py' -->\r\n\r\n```python\r\nimport numpy as np\r\nnp.testing.assert_array_less(1, np.zeros((91, 1)))\r\n```\r\n\r\n<!-- Remove these sections for a feature request -->\r\n\r\n### Error message:\r\n\r\n```\r\nTraceback (most recent call last):\r\n  File \"<string>\", line 2, in <module>\r\n  File \"[snip]/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/numpy/testing/_private/utils.py\", line 1095, in assert_array_less\r\n    equal_inf=False)\r\n  File \"[snip]/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/numpy/testing/_private/utils.py\", line 827, in assert_array_compare\r\n    raise AssertionError(msg)\r\nAssertionError: \r\nArrays are not less-ordered\r\n\r\nMismatch: 9.1e+03%\r\nMax absolute difference: 1.\r\nMax relative difference: inf\r\n x: array(1)\r\n y: array([[0.],\r\n       [0.],\r\n       [0.],...\r\n```\r\n\r\nI would expect mismatch to be 100%, not over 9000.\r\n\r\n### Numpy/Python version information:\r\n\r\n1.16.4 3.7.3 (default, May 10 2019, 14:46:04) \r\n[Clang 10.0.1 (clang-1001.0.46.4)]\r\n\r\n\r\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 624352,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/borispf",
        "type": "User",
        "login": "borispf",
        "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjYyNDM1Mg==",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "When the first argument to `np.testing.assert_array_less` is a scalar, the mismatch percentage reported is 100% * <number of mismatched items>, which can be arbitrarily large.

The error seems to be in `numpy.testing._private.utils.assert_array_compare` on [this line](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/a1cd310ea6192945b7f4e452ad5794b291da77a5/numpy/testing/_private/utils.py#L807):

```python
mismatch = 100. * (reduced.size - reduced.sum(dtype=intp)) / ox.size
```

Maybe that line could be:

```python
mismatch = 100. * (reduced.size - reduced.sum(dtype=intp)) / max(ox.size, oy.size)
```

I would be happy to implement such a small fix and write a test for it if someone is able to review it.

### Reproducing code example:

<!-- A short code example that reproduces the problem/missing feature. It should be
self-contained, i.e., possible to run as-is via 'python myproblem.py' -->

```python
import numpy as np
np.testing.assert_array_less(1, np.zeros((91, 1)))
```

<!-- Remove these sections for a feature request -->

### Error message:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 2, in <module>
  File "[snip]/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/numpy/testing/_private/utils.py", line 1095, in assert_array_less
    equal_inf=False)
  File "[snip]/.venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/numpy/testing/_private/utils.py", line 827, in assert_array_compare
    raise AssertionError(msg)
AssertionError: 
Arrays are not less-ordered

Mismatch: 9.1e+03%
Max absolute difference: 1.
Max relative difference: inf
 x: array(1)
 y: array([[0.],
       [0.],
       [0.],...
```

I would expect mismatch to be 100%, not over 9000.

### Numpy/Python version information:

1.16.4 3.7.3 (default, May 10 2019, 14:46:04) 
[Clang 10.0.1 (clang-1001.0.46.4)]


"
    ],
    "title": [
        "np.testing.assert_array_less "Mismatch:" wrong with scalar first argument"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "00 - Bug",
            "description": null
        },
        {
            "name": "component: numpy.testing",
            "description": null
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question
pkg.installed does not honor the normalize parameter. This prevents the installation of packages containing an arch as part of the name (eg: uptrack-updates-3.10.0-693.11.1.el7.x86_64)

### Setup
Installed package : 
```
# yum info uptrack-updates-3.10.0-693.11.1.el7.x86_64
Loaded plugins: ulninfo
Installed Packages
Name        : uptrack-updates-3.10.0-693.11.1.el7.x86_64
Arch        : noarch
Version     : 20180309
Release     : 0
Size        : 4.4 M
Repo        : installed
```

test.sls : 
```
install-utrack:
  pkg.installed:
    - name: uptrack-updates-3.10.0-693.11.1.el7.x86_64
    - normalize: False
```

Expected result : 
```
# salt 'uptrack-test' state.apply test
uptrack-test:
  Name: uptrack-updates-3.10.0-693.11.1.el7.x86_64 - Function: pkg.installed - Result: Clean Started: - 11:24:56.684679 Duration: 1431.48 ms
```

Actual result: 
```
# salt 'uptrack-test' state.apply test
uptrack-test:
----------
          ID: install-utrack
    Function: pkg.installed

    "id": 244513187,

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\nhttps://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/topics/installation/windows.html has links to installers https://repo.saltstack.com/windows/Salt-Minion-2017.7.0-x86-Setup.exe and\r\nhttps://repo.saltstack.com/windows/Salt-Minion-2017.7.0-AMD64-Setup.exe,\r\nbut as of 2017.7.0, the installers have a new naming convention, so the links are broken.\r\n\r\nThere are now python2 and python3 versions available:\r\nSalt-Minion-2017.7.0-Py2-x86-Setup.exe\r\nSalt-Minion-2017.7.0-Py3-x86-Setup.exe.\r\nPerhaps it should link to both, with an explanation of the difference or a link to why there is a difference?\r\n\r\n",

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

I'm trying to parse the output of a Powershell command as a prerequisite for some other states, by utilising `stateful` and `watch`. (First time using Salt, so please educate me if I'm doing this wrong!).

When running my multi-line, Powershell `cmd.run`, I'm getting the following error from Powershell -  `Missing closing '}' in statement block.`. If I run the command directly in Powershell that's produced from the Salt state, it works just fine (See below).

### Setup

Run `salt 'testvm' state.apply updates.wmf5_1`

`/srv/salt/updates/wmf5_1.sls`
```yaml
Check if WMF 5.1 is installed:
  cmd.run:
    - name: |
          try {
            get-hotfix -id {{ hotfix_id }} -Ea Stop | Out-Null
            return [psobject]@{ 'changed' = $True }
          } catch {
            return
          }
    - shell: powershell
    - stateful: True
```
Output:
```
          ID: Check if WMF 5.1 is installed
    Function: cmd.run
        Name: try {
  get-hotfix -id KB3191564 -Ea Stop | Out-Null
  return [psobject]@{ 'changed' = $True }
} catch {
  return 
}

      Result: True
     Comment: Missing closing '}' in statement block.
                  + CategoryInfo          : ParserError: (:) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordEx 
                 ception
                  + FullyQualifiedErrorId : MissingEndCurlyBrace
     Started: 20:24:23.935000
    Duration: 339.0 ms
     Changes:   
```


### Steps to Reproduce Issue

Apply state on test 2012 R2 host.

### Versions Report

Master
```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.11.5
 
Dependency Versions:
           cffi: 0.8.6
       cherrypy: 3.5.0
       dateutil: 2.2

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\nsmtp.send_msg's profile is kind of useless.\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\n```\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2016.11.4\r\n\r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: 1.9.1\r\n       cherrypy: unknown\r\n       dateutil: 2.5.3\r\n      docker-py: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: 2.0.0\r\n      gitpython: 2.1.1\r\n          ioflo: 1.6.7\r\n         Jinja2: 2.8\r\n        libgit2: Not Installed\r\n        libnacl: 1.5.0\r\n       M2Crypto: 0.22\r\n           Mako: Not Installed\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.4.6\r\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\r\n      pycparser: 2.17\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n   pycryptodome: Not Installed\r\n         pygit2: Not Installed\r\n         Python: 2.7.12 (default, Dec 31 2016, 10:50:46)\r\n   python-gnupg: 2.2.0\r\n         PyYAML: 3.12\r\n          PyZMQ: 16.0.2\r\n           RAET: 0.6.6\r\n          smmap: 0.9.0\r\n        timelib: 0.2.4\r\n        Tornado: 4.3\r\n            ZMQ: 4.1.4\r\n\r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist:\r\n        machine: i86pc\r\n        release: 5.11\r\n         system: SunOS\r\n        version: Not Installed\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\n```\r\ntest:\r\n  smtp.send_msg:\r\n    - profile: smtp-default\r\n    - recipient: \"sjorge@example.org\"\r\n    - subject: \"hello\"\r\n    - name: \"hello, i'm your friendly local salt minion\"\r\n```\r\nResults in\r\n\r\n```\r\nlocal:\r\n----------\r\n          ID: test\r\n    Function: smtp.send_msg\r\n        Name: more text\r\n      Result: False\r\n     Comment: Missing parameter sender for state smtp.send_msg\r\n     Changes:\r\n```\r\n\r\nsender is already defined in the smtp profile (minion.d/smtp.conf)\r\n```\r\nsmtp-default:\r\n  smtp.sender: salt@example.org\r\n  smtp.server: server.example.org\r\n  smtp.tls: false\r\n```\r\n\r\nI would expect the state to try and fill in the blanks from the profile before complaining first.\r\n\r\ne.g. ```salt-call smtp.send_msg 'sjorge@example.org' 'hello'  profile='smtp-default'```\r\n\r\nWorks like that.\r\n\r\n",

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question
smtp.send_msg's profile is kind of useless.

### Setup
```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.11.4

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: 1.9.1
       cherrypy: unknown
       dateutil: 2.5.3
      docker-py: Not Installed
          gitdb: 2.0.0
      gitpython: 2.1.1
          ioflo: 1.6.7
         Jinja2: 2.8
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: 1.5.0
       M2Crypto: 0.22
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: 2.17
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
   pycryptodome: Not Installed
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.12 (default, Dec 31 2016, 10:50:46)
   python-gnupg: 2.2.0
         PyYAML: 3.12
          PyZMQ: 16.0.2
           RAET: 0.6.6
          smmap: 0.9.0
        timelib: 0.2.4
        Tornado: 4.3
            ZMQ: 4.1.4

System Versions:
           dist:
        machine: i86pc
        release: 5.11
         system: SunOS
        version: Not Installed
```

### Steps to Reproduce Issue
```
test:
  smtp.send_msg:
    - profile: smtp-default
    - recipient: "sjorge@example.org"
    - subject: "hello"
    - name: "hello, i'm your friendly local salt minion"
```
Results in

```
local:
----------
          ID: test
    Function: smtp.send_msg
        Name: more text
      Result: False
     Comment: Missing parameter sender for state smtp.send_msg
     Changes:
```

sender is already defined in the smtp profile (minion.d/smtp.conf)
```
smtp-default:
  smtp.sender: salt@example.org
  smtp.server: server.example.org
  smtp.tls: false
```

I would expect the state to try and fill in the blanks from the profile before complaining first.

e.g. ```salt-call smtp.send_msg 'sjorge@example.org' 'hello'  profile='smtp-default'```

Works like that.

"
    ],
    "title": [
        "smtp.send_msg state oddities"

}

body:
{
    "id": 196146226,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/38318",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question
trying to help someone earlyer today i setup a test to make sure what i was saying would be true. 
my test consisted of 2 file.recurse states. one requiring the other. the one with the require also had clean: True

when i ran the state it ran as expecting creating the directory and populating it with both file.recurse items. however when i deleted an item from one of the source directories. it was not being deleted with a rerun of the state. 

remove the recurse and clean ran properly. deleted everything not in the single file.recurse [including the other file.recurse files]

readd the require and files were created properly. 
touch a file in the target directory and clean did not remove it. 

### Setup
2 states

```
recurse1:
  file.recurse:
    - name: /tmp/testing
    - source: salt://testing/files/recurse1

recurse2:
  file.recurse:
    - name: /tmp/testing
    - source: salt://testing/files/recurse2
    - clean: True
    - require:
      - file: recurse1
```

contents of sources
```
cd recurse1
[root@salt01 recurse1]# ls
a  b  c
[root@salt01 recurse1]# cd ..
[root@salt01 files]# cd recurse2
[root@salt01 recurse2]# ls
d  e
```
after the first run /tmp/testing will have a,b,c,d,e
if you then touch a file in /tmp/testing or delete a file out of either of the sources
that file will not be removed in the target on following runs of the state.
remove the require and everything works as it should [the first recursive runs finds everything is ok. the second deletes everything that doesn't belong to it.]


```
[root@salt01 testing]# touch file
[root@salt01 testing]# ls
a  b  c  d  e  file
[root@salt01 testing]# salt-call state.apply testing.test
local:

Total run time: 123.221 ms
[root@salt01 testing]# ls
a  b  c  d  e  file
[root@salt01 testing]#
```

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question
trying to help someone earlyer today i setup a test to make sure what i was saying would be true. 
my test consisted of 2 file.recurse states. one requiring the other. the one with the require also had clean: True

when i ran the state it ran as expecting creating the directory and populating it with both file.recurse items. however when i deleted an item from one of the source directories. it was not being deleted with a rerun of the state. 

remove the recurse and clean ran properly. deleted everything not in the single file.recurse [including the other file.recurse files]

readd the require and files were created properly. 
touch a file in the target directory and clean did not remove it. 

### Setup
2 states

```
recurse1:
  file.recurse:
    - name: /tmp/testing
    - source: salt://testing/files/recurse1

recurse2:
  file.recurse:
    - name: /tmp/testing
    - source: salt://testing/files/recurse2
    - clean: True
    - require:
      - file: recurse1
```

contents of sources
```
cd recurse1
[root@salt01 recurse1]# ls
a  b  c
[root@salt01 recurse1]# cd ..
[root@salt01 files]# cd recurse2
[root@salt01 recurse2]# ls
d  e
```
after the first run /tmp/testing will have a,b,c,d,e
if you then touch a file in /tmp/testing or delete a file out of either of the sources
that file will not be removed in the target on following runs of the state.
remove the require and everything works as it should [the first recursive runs finds everything is ok. the second deletes everything that doesn't belong to it.]


```
[root@salt01 testing]# touch file
[root@salt01 testing]# ls
a  b  c  d  e  file
[root@salt01 testing]# salt-call state.apply testing.test
local:
----------
          ID: recurse1
    Function: file.recurse
        Name: /tmp/testing
      Result: True
     Comment: The directory /tmp/testing is in the correct state
     Started: 12:13:11.322959
    Duration: 89.382 ms
     Changes:
----------
          ID: recurse2
    Function: file.recurse
        Name: /tmp/testing
      Result: True
     Comment: The directory /tmp/testing is in the correct state
     Started: 12:13:11.412760
    Duration: 33.839 ms
     Changes:

Summary for local
------------
Succeeded: 2
Failed:    0
------------
Total states run:     2
Total run time: 123.221 ms
[root@salt01 testing]# ls
a  b  c  d  e  file
[root@salt01 testing]#
```

body:
{
    "id": 188907606,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/37656",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/pkg/windows/installer/Salt-Minion-Setup.nsi\r\ncontains logig for an an upgrade.\r\n\r\nFunction ```getMinionConfig``` reads an existing configuration file (salt/conf/minion),\r\nBut it reads only two items: 'master:' and 'id:' (the minion-name) \r\nAll other configuration is ignored.\r\n\r\nThe code for the two items is \r\n```${StrLoc} $2 $1 \"master:\" \">\" ``` and \r\n```${StrLoc} $2 $1 \"id:\" \">\"```\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\nAny Windows \r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\nInstall any version\r\nstop salt-minion.\r\nopen ```salt/conf/minion```\r\nfind ```# retry_dns: 30```\r\nchange to ```retry_dns: 31```\r\nInstall a later Salt version\r\nopen ```salt/conf/minion```\r\nfind ```# retry_dns: 30```\r\n\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\nAny version\r\n\r\n",

{
    "id": 21640256,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/8119",
    "body": "I'd like to control the insertion and removal of DNS records and DHCP leases/reservations in Active Directory for all of our Linux hosts/VMs. These hosts/VMs can easily have at least 4 IPs each depending which VLANs they have access to and it's really hard to maintain this manually and I'd prefer not to have to write powershell to do all of this if possible (I've written some of it with WMI and powershell and I can't say I enjoy it).\n\nSo before we get too far, I'd just like to be able to get basic command execution returning results.\n\nI'm finding cmd.run isn't executing my calls to dnscmd with sufficient privileges (not surprising):\n\nwhen run in a command prompt with my A/D Domain admin user:\n\n```\n\nC:\\>dnscmd dc-name-goes-here /enumzones\n\nEnumerated zone list:\n        Zone count = 17\n\n Zone name                      Type       Storage         Properties\n\n .                              Cache      AD-Domain\n _msdcs.domain.org            Primary    AD-Forest       Secure Aging\n a.b.in-addr.arpa              Primary    AD-Forest       Update Rev Aging\n c.d.e.in-addr.arpa          Primary    AD-Domain       Secure Rev Aging\n <snip>\n domain2.org                  Forwarder  AD-Forest\n domain.org                   Primary    AD-Domain       Update Aging\n TrustAnchors                   Primary    AD-Forest       Aging\n\n```\n\nHere is when I try running the same command from the same host via salt's cmd.run module on the salt master:\n\n```\n\n[root@salt-master ~]# salt -v \"win-dev*\" cmd.run \"dnscmd dc-name-goes-here /enumzones\"\nExecuting job with jid 20131026090518282166\n-------------------------------------------\n\nwin-dev:\n\n    Zone enumeration failed\n        status = 5 (0x00000005)\n    Command failed:  ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED     5    0x5\n\n```\n\nThe salt-minion is set to run as a \"Local System\" service. Do I just need to replace the \"Local System\" start as privileges with an A/D privileged service account that has a tailored permission set for the service access we need?\n\nI tried to in fact do this but I can't get the salt-minion service to start when I change the \"Log On As\" user to a privileged A/D account. \n\nThe error is as follows:\n\n```\n\nWindows could not start the salt-minion service on Local Computer.\n\nError 5: Access is Denied.\n\n```\n\nI try the same thing with shelled out calls to netsh dhcp server and here it errors out but with a cryptic error that suggests something else may be in play (although permissions could be playing a role).\n\nadd a dhcp reservation from the command prompt:\n\n```\nnetsh dhcp server <dhcp-server-ip-goes-here> scope <scope-ip-goes-here> add reservedip a.b.c.d abc123abc123 test123.domain.org added-by-script\n\nChanged the current scope context to <scope-ip-goes-here> scope.\n\nCommand completed successfully.\n```\n\nwhen I try this from the salt-master via cmd-run:\n\n```\n\n[root@salt-master ~]# salt -v 'win-dev*' cmd.run \"netsh dhcp server <dhcp-server-ip-goes-here> scope <scope-ip-goes-here> add reservedip a.b.c.d abc123abc123 test123.domain.org added-by-script\"\n\nExecuting job with jid 20131026155559514704\n-------------------------------------------\n\nwin-dev.trailmix.net:\n\n    The command needs a valid Scope IP Address.\n\n```\n\nNormally I would think I've entered something in wrong, but I'm literally copying and pasting commands from the command prompt and what I'm trying to execute via cmd.run via salt. Is this just a poorly worded error message associated with salt not having access to the referenced scope in DHCP? I can't tell.\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "I'd like to control the insertion and removal of DNS records and DHCP leases/reservations in Active Directory for all of our Linux hosts/VMs. These hosts/VMs can easily have at least 4 IPs each depending which VLANs they have access to and it's really hard to maintain this manually and I'd prefer not to have to write powershell to do all of this if possible (I've written some of it with WMI and powershell and I can't say I enjoy it).

So before we get too far, I'd just like to be able to get basic command execution returning results.

I'm finding cmd.run isn't executing my calls to dnscmd with sufficient privileges (not surprising):

when run in a command prompt with my A/D Domain admin user:

```

C:\>dnscmd dc-name-goes-here /enumzones

Enumerated zone list:
        Zone count = 17

 Zone name                      Type       Storage         Properties

 .                              Cache      AD-Domain
 _msdcs.domain.org            Primary    AD-Forest       Secure Aging
 a.b.in-addr.arpa              Primary    AD-Forest       Update Rev Aging
 c.d.e.in-addr.arpa          Primary    AD-Domain       Secure Rev Aging
 <snip>
 domain2.org                  Forwarder  AD-Forest
 domain.org                   Primary    AD-Domain       Update Aging
 TrustAnchors                   Primary    AD-Forest       Aging

```

Here is when I try running the same command from the same host via salt's cmd.run module on the salt master:

```

[root@salt-master ~]# salt -v "win-dev*" cmd.run "dnscmd dc-name-goes-here /enumzones"
Executing job with jid 20131026090518282166
-------------------------------------------

win-dev:

    Zone enumeration failed
        status = 5 (0x00000005)
    Command failed:  ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED     5    0x5

```

The salt-minion is set to run as a "Local System" service. Do I just need to replace the "Local System" start as privileges with an A/D privileged service account that has a tailored permission set for the service access we need?

I tried to in fact do this but I can't get the salt-minion service to start when I change the "Log On As" user to a privileged A/D account. 

The error is as follows:

```

Windows could not start the salt-minion service on Local Computer.

Error 5: Access is Denied.

```

I try the same thing with shelled out calls to netsh dhcp server and here it errors out but with a cryptic error that suggests something else may be in play (although permissions could be playing a role).

add a dhcp reservation from the command prompt:

```
netsh dhcp server <dhcp-server-ip-goes-here> scope <scope-ip-goes-here> add reservedip a.b.c.d abc123abc123 test123.domain.org added-by-script

Changed the current scope context to <scope-ip-goes-here> scope.

Command completed successfully.
```

when I try this from the salt-master via cmd-run:

```

[root@salt-master ~]# salt -v 'win-dev*' cmd.run "netsh dhcp server <dhcp-server-ip-goes-here> scope <scope-ip-goes-here> add reservedip a.b.c.d abc123abc123 test123.domain.org added-by-script"

Executing job with jid 20131026155559514704
-------------------------------------------

win-dev.trailmix.net:

    The command needs a valid Scope IP Address.

```

Normally I would think I've entered something in wrong, but I'm literally copying and pasting commands from the command prompt and what I'm trying to execute via cmd.run via salt. Is this just a poorly worded error message associated with salt not having access to the referenced scope in DHCP? I can't tell.
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "cmd.run priviliges on windows minion"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Feature",
            "description": "new functionality including changes to functionality and code refactors, etc."
        },
        {
            "name": "Platform",
            "description": "Relates to OS, containers, platform-based utilities like FS, system based apps"
        },
        {
            "name": "Windows",
            "description": null
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "On CentOS6 mysql user is no longer created correctly, whether password or password_hash is used.\nFor example:\n\n``` salt\nmysql-user-add-{{user.user}}-{{host}}:\n  mysql_user.present:\n    - name: {{user.user}}\n    - password_hash: '{{user.password_hash}}'\n    - host: '{{host}}'\n```\n\nresults in:\n\n``` yaml\n          ID: mysql-user-add-mysql-test-localhost\n    Function: mysql_user.present\n        Name: mysql-test\n      Result: False\n     Comment: MySQL Error 1054: Unknown column 'Password' in 'where clause'\n     Started: 05:46:35.532327\n    Duration: 5.064 ms\n```\n\nThis is most likely related to changes in MySQL 5.7: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/account-upgrades.html\n\nSalt versions report: \n\n``` yaml\n           Salt: 2015.5.6\n         Python: 2.6.6 (r266:84292, Jul 23 2015, 15:22:56)\n         Jinja2: 2.8\n       M2Crypto: 0.20.2\n msgpack-python: 0.4.6\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n         PyYAML: 3.11\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n          PyZMQ: 14.5.0\n           RAET: Not Installed\n            ZMQ: 4.0.5\n           Mako: Not Installed\n        Tornado: Not Installed\n        timelib: 0.2.4\n       dateutil: Not Installed\n```\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "On CentOS6 mysql user is no longer created correctly, whether password or password_hash is used.
For example:

``` salt
mysql-user-add-{{user.user}}-{{host}}:
  mysql_user.present:
    - name: {{user.user}}
    - password_hash: '{{user.password_hash}}'
    - host: '{{host}}'
```

results in:

``` yaml
          ID: mysql-user-add-mysql-test-localhost
    Function: mysql_user.present
        Name: mysql-test
      Result: False
     Comment: MySQL Error 1054: Unknown column 'Password' in 'where clause'
     Started: 05:46:35.532327
    Duration: 5.064 ms
```

This is most likely related to changes in MySQL 5.7: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/account-upgrades.html

Salt versions report: 

``` yaml
           Salt: 2015.5.6
         Python: 2.6.6 (r266:84292, Jul 23 2015, 15:22:56)
         Jinja2: 2.8
       M2Crypto: 0.20.2
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
        libnacl: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          ioflo: Not Installed
          PyZMQ: 14.5.0
           RAET: Not Installed
            ZMQ: 4.0.5
           Mako: Not Installed
        Tornado: Not Installed
        timelib: 0.2.4
       dateutil: Not Installed
```
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "mysql_user.present does not work with MySQL 5.7"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "Execution-Module",
            "description": ""

            "description": "fix is linked, bug author to confirm fix"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-medium",
            "description": "3rd level, incorrect or bad functionality, confusing and lacks a work around"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "`pkg search` starting from version 1.6.0 defaults to show comments what makes at least `pkg.latest` got broken:\n\n``` yaml\n[...]\n[INFO    ] Executing state pkg.latest for pkg\n[INFO    ] Executing command 'pkg info -ao' in directory '/home/yz'\n[INFO    ] Executing command 'pkg search pkg' in directory '/home/yz'\n[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad pkg.version_cmp\n[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad pkg.normalize_name\n[INFO    ] Executing command 'pkg install  -y pkg' in directory '/home/yz'\n[INFO    ] Executing command 'pkg info -ao' in directory '/home/yz'\n[ERROR   ] Package pkg failed to update.\n[INFO    ] Completed state [pkg] at time 13:30:27.804182\n[DEBUG   ] File /var/cache/salt/minion/accumulator/34577839904 does not exist, no need to cleanup.\n[DEBUG   ] Initializing new AsyncZeroMQReqChannel for ('/usr/local/etc/salt/pki/minion', 'dt-bal02', 'tcp://192.168.90.19:4506', 'aes')\n[DEBUG   ] Initializing new SAuth for ('/usr/local/etc/salt/pki/minion', 'dt-bal02', 'tcp://192.168.90.19:4506')\n[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded highstate.output\nlocal:\n----------\n          ID: pkg\n    Function: pkg.latest\n      Result: False\n     Comment: Package pkg failed to update.\n     Started: 13:30:26.840506\n    Duration: 963.676 ms\n     Changes:\n\nSummary for local\n------------\nSucceeded: 0\nFailed:    1\n------------\nTotal states run:     1\nTotal run time: 963.676 ms\n```\n\nPlease, consider checking `pkg` version and adding `-q` if version >= 1.6.0 (`pkg search -q pkg_name`) and please help me fix this until release, as I've got a bunch of my `sls`'s broken =( Would it be sufficient to just add `-q` into `cmd` definition in function `latest_version` in `python2.7/site-packages/salt/modules/pkgng.py`?\n",

{
    "body": [
        "`pkg search` starting from version 1.6.0 defaults to show comments what makes at least `pkg.latest` got broken:

``` yaml
[...]
[INFO    ] Executing state pkg.latest for pkg
[INFO    ] Executing command 'pkg info -ao' in directory '/home/yz'
[INFO    ] Executing command 'pkg search pkg' in directory '/home/yz'
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad pkg.version_cmp
[DEBUG   ] Could not LazyLoad pkg.normalize_name
[INFO    ] Executing command 'pkg install  -y pkg' in directory '/home/yz'
[INFO    ] Executing command 'pkg info -ao' in directory '/home/yz'
[ERROR   ] Package pkg failed to update.
[INFO    ] Completed state [pkg] at time 13:30:27.804182
[DEBUG   ] File /var/cache/salt/minion/accumulator/34577839904 does not exist, no need to cleanup.
[DEBUG   ] Initializing new AsyncZeroMQReqChannel for ('/usr/local/etc/salt/pki/minion', 'dt-bal02', 'tcp://192.168.90.19:4506', 'aes')
[DEBUG   ] Initializing new SAuth for ('/usr/local/etc/salt/pki/minion', 'dt-bal02', 'tcp://192.168.90.19:4506')
[DEBUG   ] LazyLoaded highstate.output
local:
----------
          ID: pkg
    Function: pkg.latest
      Result: False
     Comment: Package pkg failed to update.
     Started: 13:30:26.840506
    Duration: 963.676 ms
     Changes:

Summary for local
------------
Succeeded: 0
Failed:    1
------------
Total states run:     1
Total run time: 963.676 ms
```

Please, consider checking `pkg` version and adding `-q` if version >= 1.6.0 (`pkg search -q pkg_name`) and please help me fix this until release, as I've got a bunch of my `sls`'s broken =( Would it be sufficient to just add `-q` into `cmd` definition in function `latest_version` in `python2.7/site-packages/salt/modules/pkgng.py`?
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "[FreeBSD] "pkg search" behavior changed since 1.5 series"

    "body": "Versions:

```
# salt --versions

I set up the [ec2-autoscale reactor](https://github.com/saltstack-formulas/ec2-autoscale-reactor) but modified it to run a script rather than calling salt-cloud. When the reactor is triggered, the script doesn't run, and the debug output from the master reports a warning that says "Exception caught by reactor: cmd_async() takes at least 3 arguments (2 given)"

This is the reactor which results in the warning:

```
#!py

import pprint
import os
import time
import json
import requests
import binascii
import M2Crypto
import salt.utils.smtp as smtp
import salt.config as config


def run():
    '''
    Run the reactor
    '''
    sns = data['post']

    if 'SubscribeURL' in sns:
        # This is just a subscription notification
        msg_kwargs = {
            'smtp.subject': 'EC2 Autoscale Subscription (via Salt Reactor)',
            'smtp.content': '{0}\r\n'.format(pprint.pformat(sns)),
        }
        smtp.send(msg_kwargs, __opts__)
        return {}

    url_check = sns['SigningCertURL'].replace('https://', '')
    url_comps = url_check.split('/')
    if not url_comps[0].endswith('.amazonaws.com'):
        # The expected URL does not seem to come from Amazon, do not try to
        # process it
        msg_kwargs = {
            'smtp.subject': 'EC2 Autoscale SigningCertURL Error (via Salt Reactor)',
            'smtp.content': (
                'There was an error with the EC2 SigningCertURL. '
                '\r\n{1} \r\n{2} \r\n'
                'Content received was:\r\n\r\n{0}\r\n').format(
                    pprint.pformat(sns), url_check, url_comps[0]
                ),
        }
        smtp.send(msg_kwargs, __opts__)
        return {}

    if not 'Subject' in sns:
        sns['Subject'] = ''

    pem_request = requests.request('GET', sns['SigningCertURL'])
    pem = pem_request.text

    str_to_sign = (
        'Message\n{Message}\n'
        'MessageId\n{MessageId}\n'
        'Subject\n{Subject}\n'
        'Timestamp\n{Timestamp}\n'
        'TopicArn\n{TopicArn}\n'
        'Type\n{Type}\n'
    ).format(**sns)

    cert = M2Crypto.X509.load_cert_string(str(pem))
    pubkey = cert.get_pubkey()
    pubkey.reset_context(md='sha1')
    pubkey.verify_init()
    pubkey.verify_update(str_to_sign.encode())

    decoded = binascii.a2b_base64(sns['Signature'])
    result = pubkey.verify_final(decoded)

    if result != 1:
        msg_kwargs = {
            'smtp.subject': 'EC2 Autoscale Signature Error (via Salt Reactor)',
            'smtp.content': (
                'There was an error with the EC2 Signature. '
                'Content received was:\r\n\r\n{0}\r\n').format(
                    pprint.pformat(sns)
                ),
        }
        smtp.send(msg_kwargs, __opts__)
        return {}

    message = json.loads(sns['Message'])
    instance_id = str(message['EC2InstanceId'])
    instance_code = instance_id[2:]

    if 'launch' in sns['Subject']:
        # This section has been modified
        # Instead of running salt-cloud, it will run a script to
        #  configure the minion, and then accept the key
        ret = {
            'ec2_autoscale_minion_config': {
                'cmd.run': [
                    {'name': '/root/minion-setup ' + instance_id}
                ]
            },
            'ec2_autoscale_accept_key': {
                'wheel.key.accept': [
                    {'match': '*' + instance_code},
                ]
            }
        }
    elif 'termination' in sns['Subject']:
        ret = {
            'ec2_autoscale_termination': {
                'wheel.key.delete': [
                    {'match': '*' + instance_code},
                ]
            }
        }

    return ret

```

I created a state with the python renderer which calls the same script, and I was able to run it successfully. Here is the state file:

```
#!py

import pprint
import os
import time
import json
import requests
import binascii
import M2Crypto
import salt.utils.smtp as smtp
import salt.config as config


def run():
    instance_id = 'i-ed7aa63e'
    instance_code = instance_id[2:]
    ret = {
        'ec2_autoscale_minion_config': {
            'cmd.run': [
                {'name': '/root/minion-setup ' + instance_id},
                {'cwd': '/root'}
            ]
        }
    }
    return ret
```

{
    "body": [
        "Versions:

```
# salt --versions
                  Salt: 2015.5.0
                Python: 2.7.6 (default, Jun 22 2015, 17:58:13)
                Jinja2: 2.7.2

                  RAET: Not Installed
                   ZMQ: 4.0.4
                  Mako: 0.9.1
 Debian source package: 2015.5.0+ds-1trusty1
```

I set up the [ec2-autoscale reactor](https://github.com/saltstack-formulas/ec2-autoscale-reactor) but modified it to run a script rather than calling salt-cloud. When the reactor is triggered, the script doesn't run, and the debug output from the master reports a warning that says "Exception caught by reactor: cmd_async() takes at least 3 arguments (2 given)"

This is the reactor which results in the warning:

```
#!py

import pprint
import os
import time
import json
import requests
import binascii
import M2Crypto
import salt.utils.smtp as smtp
import salt.config as config


def run():
    '''
    Run the reactor
    '''
    sns = data['post']

    if 'SubscribeURL' in sns:
        # This is just a subscription notification
        msg_kwargs = {
            'smtp.subject': 'EC2 Autoscale Subscription (via Salt Reactor)',
            'smtp.content': '{0}\r\n'.format(pprint.pformat(sns)),
        }
        smtp.send(msg_kwargs, __opts__)
        return {}

    url_check = sns['SigningCertURL'].replace('https://', '')
    url_comps = url_check.split('/')
    if not url_comps[0].endswith('.amazonaws.com'):
        # The expected URL does not seem to come from Amazon, do not try to
        # process it
        msg_kwargs = {
            'smtp.subject': 'EC2 Autoscale SigningCertURL Error (via Salt Reactor)',
            'smtp.content': (
                'There was an error with the EC2 SigningCertURL. '
                '\r\n{1} \r\n{2} \r\n'
                'Content received was:\r\n\r\n{0}\r\n').format(
                    pprint.pformat(sns), url_check, url_comps[0]
                ),
        }
        smtp.send(msg_kwargs, __opts__)
        return {}

    if not 'Subject' in sns:
        sns['Subject'] = ''

    pem_request = requests.request('GET', sns['SigningCertURL'])
    pem = pem_request.text

    str_to_sign = (
        'Message\n{Message}\n'
        'MessageId\n{MessageId}\n'
        'Subject\n{Subject}\n'
        'Timestamp\n{Timestamp}\n'
        'TopicArn\n{TopicArn}\n'
        'Type\n{Type}\n'
    ).format(**sns)

    cert = M2Crypto.X509.load_cert_string(str(pem))
    pubkey = cert.get_pubkey()
    pubkey.reset_context(md='sha1')
    pubkey.verify_init()
    pubkey.verify_update(str_to_sign.encode())

    decoded = binascii.a2b_base64(sns['Signature'])
    result = pubkey.verify_final(decoded)

    if result != 1:
        msg_kwargs = {
            'smtp.subject': 'EC2 Autoscale Signature Error (via Salt Reactor)',
            'smtp.content': (
                'There was an error with the EC2 Signature. '
                'Content received was:\r\n\r\n{0}\r\n').format(
                    pprint.pformat(sns)
                ),
        }
        smtp.send(msg_kwargs, __opts__)
        return {}

    message = json.loads(sns['Message'])
    instance_id = str(message['EC2InstanceId'])
    instance_code = instance_id[2:]

    if 'launch' in sns['Subject']:
        # This section has been modified
        # Instead of running salt-cloud, it will run a script to
        #  configure the minion, and then accept the key
        ret = {
            'ec2_autoscale_minion_config': {
                'cmd.run': [
                    {'name': '/root/minion-setup ' + instance_id}
                ]
            },
            'ec2_autoscale_accept_key': {
                'wheel.key.accept': [
                    {'match': '*' + instance_code},
                ]
            }
        }
    elif 'termination' in sns['Subject']:
        ret = {
            'ec2_autoscale_termination': {
                'wheel.key.delete': [
                    {'match': '*' + instance_code},
                ]
            }
        }

    return ret

```

I created a state with the python renderer which calls the same script, and I was able to run it successfully. Here is the state file:

```
#!py

import pprint
import os
import time
import json
import requests
import binascii
import M2Crypto
import salt.utils.smtp as smtp
import salt.config as config


def run():
    instance_id = 'i-ed7aa63e'
    instance_code = instance_id[2:]
    ret = {
        'ec2_autoscale_minion_config': {
            'cmd.run': [
                {'name': '/root/minion-setup ' + instance_id},
                {'cwd': '/root'}
            ]
        }
    }
    return ret
```
